snippet.textDisplay: Hello, Wanted to provide a further update. It is 3/2/2020 at 3:25pm. There has been a Go Fund Me made by the Community Youth Center of San Francisco. They have been speaking to the elderly man and have been representing him in interviews. If you would like to donate please make sure the go fund me is through the CYCSF! it is the ONLY official fundraising page for him and all proceeds will go to his family ( all others are fake). The SF district Attorney has withdrawn charges against the young man who recorded the video ( same person in my previous post) . The reason being is that the elderly man "expressed interest in a restorative justice outcome". While we do not know what exactly they mean by a "restorative justice" model , I hope that the young man does serve some sort of consequence. Please DO NOT harass the sf district attorney's office as they have been speaking to the elderly man about the incident. While it angers me that the person recording this video will not have charges against him, that is the wishes of the elderly man and although it may not seem fair to the rest of us that is his desires. Again, I pulled this info from nextshark.com 's instagram.

snippet.textDisplay:
Just to raise an observation:. After Jeanne at the beginning of the clip was a great voice in support of raising awarenesses that racism against Asian-Americans exists!, and, AMERICAN RACISM CAN BE WHITE-ON-ASIAN AND BLACK-ON-ASIAN (people only have wanted to recognize ASIAN-ON-BLACK),....
There were two subtle "sweeps-under-the-rug."
1. When Loni said, I didn't see an Asian man, I saw my grandfather. Even though in part she was trying to underscore being race-blind to his Asianness, this highlighted the elder abuse aspect and diverted away from the antiAsian reality what had just been highlighted.
2. Amanda did the same thing when she at the end listed groups and referred to the clip as elder abuse, not racism when IT WAS RACISM AND IT WAS HIS ASIANNESS THEY WERE COMING DOWN ON HIM FOR AND SAID THEY HATED.

snippet.textDisplay: Can someone shut the mouth of that girl next to Jeannie? If there's ANY chance for a person to have this much of public appearance and have her/his voice heard, you want to hear words that would not encapsulate the main issue again in a cutter wrap. Loni was totally right in saying this is someone's grandfather instead of just an asian person being molested, and then we have miss "I'm too cute but you're still asian and I'm still black" ladie on the round table? GET OUT, les estoy hablando desde Bogotá Colombia, I've been outside my country only one time and it was enough to understand the impact that a tv personality can do, this whole section of the show was a huge problem just passing by someone's (her) shoulders and not leaving a clear mark on what people should do. Black people, yes, I'm aware you might have suffered throughout the years and have stories of awful kind to share and learn from, but if you guys are preaching love and change, her words were not close to lead a movement of consciousness and tolerance. I love the show, I love your ladies, but for the longest time I have struggled with her opinions, and I don't usually participate in this community but this topic hit hard because I've felt multiple times and I myself consider that I use my life to say nothing else but words that would route anyone or anything wherever I go to a better place. snippet.textDisplay: My bf is latino, although American. When we first started dating, he always thought my demand for respect and equality from the world was kind of "radical" (I'm black), because unbeknownst to him, he was raised to generally accept racism towards him because it makes you a "good minority" to be agreeable and "grateful " for being here. Whereas being African American, I feel we (justifiably) are more concious and demanding of our rights because we have been here for generations, in many cases longer than our white counterparts. It was an educational experience for the both of us, because I didn't know that there's people who didn't speak up, and he didn't know that he had the right to do so. After 5 years of being together, we're both pretty outspoken about equality.
